abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome was highly
            successful, sustainability is likely, and institutional
            development impacts were substantial. Key lessons relate to
            public health strategies, government policies and state
            commitment, and institutional development. First, regarding
            institutional aspects, because states are the implementers
            of health programs, securing their commitment is paramount;
            thus, as demonstrated by this operation, state level health
            projects are more conducive to facilitate institutional, and
            policy reform than centrally sponsored schemes. Nonetheless,
            strong management structures, and adequate financial and
            administrative capabilities need to be in place, while
            technical functions need to be decentralized: the experiment
            of decentralizing to the district level, and strengthening
            referral committees enhanced local ownership, and
            participation, with a filtering effect on other
            tiers/programs, suggesting the need to address its success
            to the entire health system. Second, on technical and social
            aspects, the development of service norms is critical, as
            are timely disbursements, and monitoring performance, to
            ensure management decisions, and ability to document reforms
            that share experiences, and promote learning. Third, on
            operational aspects, synchronizing hardware/software
            activities is also critical, which calls for a strengthened
            procurement management regarding equipment supply, and civil
            works cost escalations.
